So in the C code, after getting the first step's result (either "Yes" or "No"), we need to process that string through this logic.

So steps for the second part:

Take the first step's result (the string "Yes" or "No") and count the frequency of each character.

Then count how many have odd counts.

Then decide based on that count.

So in code:

First, the first step's result is stored in a string, say first_result.

Then, process first_result's characters.

Initialize a frequency array (since characters are ASCII, perhaps using an array of 256 elements, or just for lowercase letters, but better to use 256 for all possible chars).

Initialize all counts to 0.

Loop through each character in first_result:

counts[ c ] +=1.

Then, loop through all counts, count how many are odd.

Read n and the string.

Process first step to get first_result (either "Yes" or "No").

Process second step on first_result to get the final output.

Now, code structure:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int main() {
    int n;
    char str[1000]; // assuming the string is not too long.

    // Read n and the string.
    // First read n:
    scanf("%d", &n);
    // consume the rest of the line (including newline)
    int c;
    while ((c = getchar()) != '\n' && c != EOF);

    // Now read the next line (the string)
    fgets(str, sizeof(str), stdin);
    // Remove the trailing newline if present
    size_t len = strlen(str);
    if (len > 0 && str[len-1] == '\n') {
        str[len-1] = '\0';
        len--;
    }

    // First step: check if the string is made of two halves equal.
    int half = n / 2;
    int same = 1;
    for (int i = 0; i < half; i++) {
        if (str[i] != str[i + half]) {
            same = 0;
            break;
        }
    }

    char first_result[4]; // "Yes" or "No" are 3 and 3 characters (including null?)
    if (same) {
        strcpy(first_result, "Yes");
    } else {
        strcpy(first_result, "No");
    }

    // Now process second step on first_result.

    // Count frequencies of each character in first_result.
    int counts[256] = {0};
    for (int i = 0; first_result[i] != '\0'; i++) {
        char c = first_result[i];
        counts[c]++;
    }

    int oddCount = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < 256; i++) {
        if (counts[i] % 2 != 0) {
            oddCount++;
        }
    }

    // Determine the output.
    if (oddCount == 0 || (oddCount % 2) == 1) {
        printf("First\n");
    } else {
        printf("Second\n");
    }

    return 0;
}
